name: maize grain production | maize grain | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/28668/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of maize grain (fresh matter) in the US state of Illinois at farm, with a pre-drying moisture content of 19.8%. This dataset includes preparation of the field prior to planting, field treatments, planting, applications of nutrients and pesticides, and harvest. Residues are not collected but remain on the field post-harvest and overwinter.;The average yield of maize grain grown in Illinois for the 2014-2021 seasons was 12,284 kg/ha (wet mass) USDA NASS (2021d). The dataset reflects the average maize grain produced in Illinois from 2014 to 2021 , inclusive, as that period allows for at least one value from USDA statistics for most parameters and generally three or more.  It reflects the mix of tillage practices (18% no till, 73% reduced till, 9% conventional tillage) (CTIC (2020a) and rotations (80% in rotation with soybean and 20% continuous corn) for maize grain.  More than 90% of maize grown is genetically engineered, almost all stacking herbicide and insect tolerance traits. This dataset reflects practices consistent with that.;Area, productivity, use of mineral and organic fertilisers and pesticides, and irrigation inputs are based on farmer data reported to the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Lime use is based on soil pH and guidance from agricultural extension offices for maize grain. Field operations and equipment types and fuel use are based on materials provided to growers by the agricultural extension office(s), including farm budgets, and on survey information agricultural extension office(s) collect from growers, in conjunction with row spacing data from USDA. Drainage (tile or ditch) is installed on 57.6% of crop land, based on state-level agricultural survey data from USDA.  Irrigation is included based on share of crop irrigated (1.4% over the time period, USDA NASS (2018d)). Chemigation is included in this and is not treated as an additional operation.;Area cultivated for maize grain in Illinois decreased by 4% between 2000 and 2021 (USDA NASS data, 5 years rolling averages). The crop LCI tool allocates land use change to all crops and activities that grew in the last 20 years in the US, and only to them, according to their respective area increase; crops for which planted area decreased are not attributed LUC impacts or credits. Thus, the amount of Land use change, annual crop is zero for maize grain grown in Illinois. The total cropland change 1997 to 2017 was -0.3% for all crops in Illinois (NRCS 2020b).;Soil characteristics are based on IFA soil survey data (pH) and NRCS and USGS analysis (SOM, clay, slope). No anti-erosion practices are assumed in the dataset; instead, the erosion soil loss reported in the U.S. Natural Resources Conservation Service's Natural Resource Inventory is used.;References: USDA NASS (2021d) Area, Production, Yield by State - Corn - 2010-2021. US Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service. https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov (direct query: https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/331F88CC-004E-34D2-B825-F8F65DAC7879);CTIC (2020a) OpTIS - Operational Tillage Information System. Conservation Technology Information Center (CTIC). https://www.ctic.org/optis_tabular_queryaccessed March 23, 2021;USDA NASS (2018d) 2018 Irrigation and Water Management Survey (2017 Census of Agriculture). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Online_Resources/Farm_and_Ranch_Irrigation_Survey/index.php;USDA NASS (2021j) Corn, Grain, Irrigated - Acres Harvested 2000-2021; Corn, Grain, Non-Irrigated - Acres Harvested 2000-2018. US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov;Iowa Soil Survey & Digital Soil Data: ISPAID. Version 8.1.1 (2017). https://www.extension.iastate.edu/soils/ispaid;NRCS (2020b)  Land Cover/use of non-Federal rural land, by State and year, in the 2017 National Resources Inventory. USDA, Natural Resources Conservation Service. http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/Internet/NRCS_RCA/reports/nri_crop_nat.html, https://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/rca/national/technical/nra/rca/text/#NRI%20Cropland

This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.

This dataset includes cultivation of the field prior to planting, field treatments, planting, applications of nutrients and pesticides, and harvest. It ends with harvested maize grain at the farm gate, prior to storage.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0111:Growing of cereals (except rice), leguminous crops and oil seeds

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The valid period covers 2014-01-01 through 2021-12-31 based on primary data sources. The production volumes, areas and applications are covered by data throughout the time period (annual for production and area, alternate years for applications). Due to disruption in 2020, some USDA data was reported for 2021 instead. Because the specific pesticides used show time-dependent trends, the most recent 3 years of data are used to avoid underweighting the most dominant pesticides currently used and to avoid skewing impacts based on compounds no longer in use. Field operations are based on current enterprise crop budgets and change little year to year.  Data for manure applications were only available for time periods prior to the valid period but represent the best available option.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Production of maize grain in Illinois (US-IL).
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset reflects current practice for maize grain in Illinois as of 2022.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Mineral fertiliser applications are crop and location (state and sub-state levels) specific for nutrient applied, based on survey data compiled by the USDA National Agricultural Statistics Service. Specific fertilisers are extrapolated from mineral fertiliser applications to  maize grain in Illinois and market consumption in the US (ecoinvent and IFA 2019).  Organic fertiliser types are extrapolated from animal manure use data for  maize grain in Illinois (state-level) based on data collected by the USDA Economic Research Service for 2010, 2005 and 2000 and current materials on livestock levels. Rotations are based on published analysis and classification of Cropland Data Layer GIS data for 2012-2018 and other sources (Socolar et al 2021). The US average is used for the state level values based on similarity shown in source maps with the exception of MO and KS (significantly more area multi-crop rotations, with rotations of alfalfa and oats).  Rotations that are predominantly corn/soy (e.g., CPCSCS & SCPCSC) have also been grouped as corn-soy rotation, assuming the overall trend will continue and the year of pasture is intermittent.  Corn in a non-repetitive rotation with anything else (>4% of land surveyed) is treated as corn-corn as the most conservative option.  The rotation pattern is assumed to be steady throughout the period, consistent with number of years classified.  Data about tillage practices are from crop-specific GIS data for corn encompassing the dataset years (OpTIS 2020).  Reduced till and high-residue (>30%) reduced till have been grouped together into a single reduced till category.  Soil characteristics, including pH and clay content, are extrapolated from data reported 2020 (pH, SOM) and 1995 (clay, slope), and taken as valid for the full time period.  Slope is consistent with 2009 USGS data showing 64% of the crop on farmland with slope under 2% and 79% less than 3%. Drainage tile data from 2012 (reported to USDA for the 2012 agricultural census) is extrapolated as valid from that date through the rest of the time period of the dataset and the distribution of drainage is treated as homogenous for all field crops. Machine usage is modelled with midwestern US diesel consumption and field operations set out by the regional agricultural extension office and crop budgets (Lazarus 2021, ISU 2015-2021).  Machine sizes (power) are approximate but based on common, recent surveys and equipment analyses (Lazarus 2021).  Transports are modelled with standard distances.  Emissions are calculated with standard methods according to ecoinvent documentation (Nemecek and Schnetzer, 2011. '01 crop production-direct field emissions natural resources' v1.2, August 2011 ) and the World Food LCA Database guidelines and the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool. Pesticide data is sometimes withheld in the NASS database to avoid disclosing data for individual operations (denoted with "D" in the data returned for the query, indicating a non-zero but withheld value). Where there is obfuscated, non-zero data for particular compounds, the crop-specific U.S. average (calculated from the USDA NASS data, which covers a subset of states, generally those with non-negligible production of the particular crop) are used.  For states with all (D) entries (i.e., the compound has been reported as used - non-zero -- but data cannot be shown), the average quantity and variability of the application rate for that compound across all of the specific crop in the US in the same time period is used. For states with a single non-D data year in the dataset timeframe, that data value is uded and the variability is set to the variability of the application rate for that compound across all of the specific crop in the US in the relevant time period. This U.S. corn average value and standard deviation is neither production nor area weighted, as the application rate depends on many factors and this value is intended to represent the range of use. Instead, the average percent of treated acres for the class in that state is used. That is, if the average share of planted area across all non-zero, non-withheld values for fungicide treatment is 15%, then the US average application rate for the withheld data fungicide is scaled by 15% to reflect the effective average treatment per ha for that compound on the particular crop in the state.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data is obtained from state, county and national statistics, agricultural extension offices, and published literature. Data for production, yields, applications of NPKS fertilisers, applications of pesticides, row width, and irrigation (if any) was obtained from the US Dept of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service and in most cases provides high-quality data spanning the dataset time period. Field operations and energy use are from enterprise crop budgets provided by local agricultural extensions offices and their farmer survey data. Literature data is used where USDA and agricultural extension guidance and data are not available. Uncertainty distribution types and statistical parameters have been based where possible on the underlying data itself, primarily normal distributions for data from USDA NASS. Otherwise, lognormal distributions are selected for use with Pedigree scores.

exchanges.description:
Emissions of heavy metals to ground water arise from leaching. These emissions are estimated  based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production).  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils)Sources for heavy metals leaching to groundwater include: Leaching of heavy metals to groundwater (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where no drainage is installed ; the share of leaching to groundwater is calculated from Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (57.9%,) and ditch drainage (7.0%). USDA (2018) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf.
(N.B. The uncertainty associated with manure data increases the uncertainty of the heavy metal emissions.)

exchanges.description:
7.52E-6 ha/kg tillage, disking (0.092 effective pass(es) per year). 
Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance. Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Field cultivation and tillage operations are specific to the tillage regime used.  The rotation pattern also dictates some tillage patterns, captured in the GIS data for tillage shares. Maize cultivation is 73% reduced till, 18% conventional tillage, and 9% no till in Illinois (CTIC 2020a). This operation applies only to conventionaly tilled fields. 
Sources:
Schnitkey G, Zulauf C, Swanson K, Paulson N (2021) "2022 Updated Crop Budgets." farmdoc daily (11):162. Department of Agricultural and Consumer Economics. https://farmdocdaily.illinois.edu/2021/12/2022-updated-crop-budgets.html; CTIC (2020a) OpTIS - Operational Tillage Information System. Land occupation per year (annual growing season).  Land is under rotation with other annual crop production (~80% corn-soy, ~20% corn-corn, Socolar et al 2021).  US NRCS data indicates that land is leaving agricultural production rather than being transitioned into it (NRCS 2020b), resulting in a flux to/from annual crop that is essentially steady state. 
Annual production is 54.8 million tonnes from 2017-2021 on 4.6 million ha planted and 4.5 million ha harvested (USDA NASS 2021d). Thus occupation is 0.81 ha/t or 8,140.93 m2/t (0.8141 m2/kg). This overall land use is split into irrigated (1.36%) and non-irrigated (98.64%) based on agricultural census data (USDA NASS 2021d) (1.1E-2 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of irrigated land, and 8.03E-1 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of non-irrigated land).

Emissions of heavy metals to soil are estimated based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The balance of heavy metal emissions to soils includes the net change from erosion, leaching, crop removal and fertilizer, manure, lime, planting and deposition.  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Heavy-metal contents of plant material, maize (mg/kg dry matter, from Freiermuth 2006). ; Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). state and regional erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (57.9%,) and ditch drainage (7.0%). USDA (2018) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf. Fertilizer, manure and pesticide application rates are based on USDA NASS data.
(N.B. The uncertainty associated with manure data increases the uncertainty of the heavy metal emissions.)

719.784 kg/ha (5.86E-2 kg/kg maize grain) solid manure loading and spreading, by hydraulic loader and spreader
The total effective manure application rate of 1,146 kg/ha (0.093 kg/kg maize grain) is calculated from USDA ERS data for amount of manure applied (18.7 T/ha; 1.52 kg/kg maize grain) on share of crop area treated (6.1%)  (years available: 2005, 2010) (USDA ARMS 2015a). The manure data has significant uncertainty due to both the age of the available data and the statistical limitations imposed by confidentiality for USDA survey respondents.
About 37% of applied manure is in liquid form, calculated from the share of dry, semi-dry and slurry and lagoon manure applied  from ARMS data.  100% of manure from cattle. The state's USDA manure table shows zero share from either swine or poultry manures.  
 Cattle manure is apportioned between solid and liquid consistent with USDA esimtated shares.
The calculated solid and liquid manure shares in this dataset are thus 37.2% solid and 62.8% liquid manure. The effective application rates are 719.8 kg solid manure per ha (3.44E-5 kg/kg maize grain) and .4 m3 liquid manure per ha (3.44E-5 m3/kg maize grain).

Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance.  (Schnitkey G, Zulauf C, Swanson K, Paulson N 2021).  Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Where an operation applies only to a portion of the harvested area, the number of passes has been scaled by the % of harvested area to which it applies (e.g., manure spreading or insecticide) as indicated by USDA statistics (applications) or USDA reports (manure use) or as otherwise indicated in enterprise crop budgets. 
Source(s): 
USDA ARMS (2015a) Agricultural Resource Management Survey (ARMS) Farm Financial and Crop Production Practices: Manure Table, Corn. USDA. https://data.ers.usda.gov/reports.aspx?ID=17883
Beegle D and Peters J. (2019) Common Manure Test Results Conversions. National Cooperative Extension Resource, Livestock And Poultry Environmental Learning Community (Lpelc). https://lpelc.org/common-manure-test-results-conversions/accessed October 5, 2021

exchanges.description:
CO2 emissions from use of urea fertilisers and lime, 90.196 kg/ha (7.34E-3 kg/kg maize grain): 41.96 kg/ha from lime and 48.24 kg/ha from urea and urea ammonium nitrate. 
Emissions are calculated following the IPCC NIR Guidelines, §11.3 and §11.4, using IPCC NIR equations 11.12 (lime) and 11.13 (urea) (mass of lime/urea * emissions factor for lime/urea) with Tier 1 emissions factors (IPCC 2006b).  EF limestone = 0.12 kg CO2-C/kg limestone (0.06-0.12, uniform) and EF urea = 0.2 kg CO2-C/kg urea (0.1-0.2, uniform) applied to both urea and the approximately 35% of UAN that is urea. The result is converted from kg CO2-C to kg CO2 (multiplying by the molar mass of CO2/mass of C in CO2 = 44.01/12) 
Sources: IPCC (2006a) 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories - Chapter 11: N2O Emissions from Managed Soils, and CO2 Emissions from Lime and Urea Application in Volume 4: Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use. 8.41E-3 kg urea/kg maize grain 
Quantities of specific fertilisers are calculated based on US fertiliser market share and nutrient compositions from the International Fertilizer Association data to supply N to meet total nutrient demand N-P-K-S: 187.13--91.13--104.06--3.92 kg/ha (USDA NASS data for 2014, 2016, 2018, 2021; reflects average over all rotations and tillage regimes) over reported cropped area of specified crop (includes all rotation patterns), meeting N demand with the IFA mix and any remaining P, K, and S demands with other fertilisers balanced to avoid exceeding other demands by more than 1%. Field cultivation and tillage operations are specific to the tillage regime used.  The rotation pattern also dictates some tillage patterns, captured in the GIS data for tillage shares. Planting on conventionally tilled fields only.

exchanges.description:
Emissions of heavy metals to soil are estimated based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The balance of heavy metal emissions to soils includes the net change from erosion, leaching, crop removal and fertilizer, manure, lime, planting and deposition.  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Heavy-metal contents of plant material, maize (mg/kg dry matter, from Freiermuth 2006). ; Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). state and regional erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (57.9%,) and ditch drainage (7.0%). USDA (2018) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf. Fertilizer, manure and pesticide application rates are based on USDA NASS data.
(N.B. The uncertainty associated with manure data increases the uncertainty of the heavy metal emissions.)
Sources:
Freiermuth (2006) SALCA-Schwermetall - Modell zur Berechnung der Schwermetall- flüsse in der Landwirtschaftlichen Ökobilanz. Agroscope FAL Zürich-Reckenholz . https://www.agroscope.admin.ch/dam/agroscope/de/dokumente/themen/umwelt-ressourcen/produktionssysteme/salca-schwermetall.pdf.download.pdf/SALCA-Schwermetall.pdf

Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance. Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Field cultivation and tillage operations are specific to the tillage regime used.  The rotation pattern also dictates some tillage patterns, captured in the GIS data for tillage shares. Maize cultivation is 73% reduced till, 18% conventional tillage, and 9% no till in Illinois (CTIC 2020a). This operation applies to reduced till fields only.

exchanges.description:
Emissions of heavy metals to soil are estimated based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The balance of heavy metal emissions to soils includes the net change from erosion, leaching, crop removal and fertilizer, manure, lime, planting and deposition.  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Heavy-metal contents of plant material, maize (mg/kg dry matter, from Freiermuth 2006). ; Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). state and regional erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (57.9%,) and ditch drainage (7.0%). USDA (2018) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf. Fertilizer, manure and pesticide application rates are based on USDA NASS data.
(N.B. The uncertainty associated with manure data increases the uncertainty of the heavy metal emissions.)

4.59E-3 kg ammonia, anhydrous, liquid/kg maize grain 
Quantities of specific fertilisers are calculated based on US fertiliser market share and nutrient compositions from the International Fertilizer Association data to supply N to meet total nutrient demand N-P-K-S: 187.13--91.13--104.06--3.92 kg/ha (USDA NASS data for 2014, 2016, 2018, 2021; reflects average over all rotations and tillage regimes) over reported cropped area of specified crop (includes all rotation patterns), meeting N demand with the IFA mix and any remaining P, K, and S demands with other fertilisers balanced to avoid exceeding other demands by more than 1%. Quantity of specific fertiliser calculated from:  quantity of N applied to treated acres times percent of planted maize acres treated (USDA NASS) times share of N supplied by compound in U.S. consumption mix (ecoinvent and International Fertilizer Association 2019) times mass compound per mass N in compound.

Phosphate leaching to ground water 0.14 kg PO4/ha (1.140E-5 kg/kg maize grain): 7.000E-2 kg PO4/ha from manure and 7.000E-2 kg PO4/ha from leaching from arable land.  Phosphate leaching to ground water is calculated using the SALCA-P model (Prasuhn 2006) with an average leaching factor for arable lands and the amount of phosphate in any applied manure, as implemented in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (see Ecoinvent_Too_Model_Description_20191015.pdf). Does not incorporate state or county data on soils, slope or conservation drainage infrastructure. Calculated with the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool. If the slope is less than 3%, no phosphate loss through run-off occurs (Prasuhn 2006). If the slope is greater or equal to 3%, phosphate loss through run-off are computed like in (Prasuhn 2006) with the site-specific correction factors set to their default value (=1):
Sources:

Emissions of heavy metals to surface water arise from leaching (when drainage is present) and erosion. Emissions are estimated  based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils)

Emissions of heavy metals to soil are estimated based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The balance of heavy metal emissions to soils includes the net change from erosion, leaching, crop removal and fertilizer, manure, lime, planting and deposition.  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Heavy-metal contents of plant material, maize (mg/kg dry matter, from Freiermuth 2006). ; Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). state and regional erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (57.9%,) and ditch drainage (7.0%). Transformation of land for planting.  Land is under rotation with other annual crop production (~80% corn-soy, ~20% corn-corn, Socolar et al 2021).  US NRCS data indicates that land is leaving agricultural production rather than being transitioned into it (NRCS 2020b), resulting in a flux to/from annual crop that is essentially steady state. 
Annual production is 54.8 million tonnes from 2017-2021 on 4.6 million ha planted and 4.5 million ha harvested (USDA NASS 2021d). Thus occupation is 0.81 ha/t or 8,140.93 m2/t (0.8141 m2/kg). This overall land use is split into irrigated (1.36%) and non-irrigated (98.64%) based on agricultural census data (USDA NASS 2021d) (1.1E-2 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of irrigated land, and 8.03E-1 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of non-irrigated land).
Sources:
USDA NASS (2021d) Area, Production, Yield by State - Corn - 2010-2021. US Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service. https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov (direct query: https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/331F88CC-004E-34D2-B825-F8F65DAC7879)
NRCS (2020b)  Land Cover/use of non-Federal rural land, by State and year, in the 2017 National Resources Inventory. USDA, Natural Resources Conservation Service. http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/Internet/NRCS_RCA/reports/nri_crop_nat.html, https://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/rca/national/technical/nra/rca/text/#NRI%20Cropland
Socolar Y, Goldstein B R, de Valpine P, Bowles T M (2021) Biophysical and policy factors predict simplified crop rotations in the US Midwest.  Environ. Res. Lett. 16 054045. . https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-9326/abf9ca

Area cultivated for maize grain in Illinois decreased by 4% between 2000 and 2021 (USDA NASS data, 5 year rolling averages). US NRCS data indicates that land is leaving agricultural production rather than being transitioned into it (NRCS 2020b), 
Calculated value from ecoinvent Crop LCI tool, 0.15137 divided by the yield in kg/ha.  Land use change is allocated to all crops and activities that grew in the last 20 years for the US, and only to them, according to their respective area increase. Crop production and natural land areas in all countries use data from 1989 to 2012 (FAOSTAT 2012), as well as for country climates and soil types (EU-JRC 2010c). Crops for which planted area decreased are not attributed LUC impacts or credits.  Land use change (LUC) combines land transformation areas calculated with the adapted 'Direct Land Use Change Assessment Tool' version 2014 developed by Blonk Consultants and the carbon losses from soil organic carbon (SOC) and vegetation (VEG) as calculated in ecoinvent v3. See 'WFLDB-Guidelines.pdf', available at https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/File/Reports.

1.42E-2 kg urea ammonium nitrate mix/kg maize grain 
Quantities of specific fertilisers are calculated based on US fertiliser market share and nutrient compositions from the International Fertilizer Association data to supply N to meet total nutrient demand N-P-K-S: 187.13--91.13--104.06--3.92 kg/ha (USDA NASS data for 2014, 2016, 2018, 2021; reflects average over all rotations and tillage regimes) over reported cropped area of specified crop (includes all rotation patterns), meeting N demand with the IFA mix and any remaining P, K, and S demands with other fertilisers balanced to avoid exceeding other demands by more than 1%. Quantity of specific fertiliser calculated from:  quantity of N applied to treated acres times percent of planted maize acres treated (USDA NASS) times share of N supplied by compound in U.S. consumption mix (ecoinvent and International Fertilizer Association 2019) times mass compound per mass N in compound.

(2019). Table 9. Percent of corn acreage receiving nitrogen fertilizer, selected States. Fertilizer Use and Price Report. Phosphorus emissions to surface water are based on the SALCA-P model (Prasuhn 2006), but using state-specific data for agricultural land (not crop-specific). The erosion and soil test values encompass the state-wide reported cropped area of maize grain in Iowa for all tillage practices (OPTiS 2020) and across all rotation patterns (Socolar et al 2021).Soil Phosphorus losses are calculated from an annual soil loss from water erosion on agricultural soils in Iowa of 12.89t/ha/year (NRCS 2020a)with a Phosphorus soil concentration of 20mg/kg soil, the median value from 1,139,873 soil test samples reported for Iowa in the 2020 Soil Test Survey, (the average of the 2005, 2010, 2015, and 2020 median soil Phosphorus concentrations is 24.mg/kg soil) (Bruulsema T and Jones J D 2021).No enrichment factor has been applied, because the phosphorus soil concentration samples are specifically agricultural land in the study area and thus any enrichment as a result of synthetic and organic fertilisers is already caputred in the soil test.An active cultivation duration of 6.8 months (0.56 year), covering cultivation through harvest (from weekly progress reports,USDA NASS 2021e), is used to adjust the annual erosion to the crop share (see Faist-Emmenegger et al 2009).No adjustment has been made for the presence of drainage (installed on 64.9% of crop land, USDA 2018) or any anti-erosion practices.Sources: 
NRCS (2020a) Soil losses from erosion (water and wind) on cultivated cropland, in the 2017 National Resources Inventory. USDA, Natural Resources Conservation Service. http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/Internet/NRCS_RCA/reports/nri_crop_nat.html
Bruulsema T and Jones J D (2021) Soil Test Summary 2020. Foundation for Agronomic Research and Plant Nutrition Canada present this 2020 summary of soil test levels in North America. Foundation for Agronomic Research, Plant Nutrition Canada. https://soiltest.tfi.org/about/about_soil_test_summaryaccessed August 30, 2021
USDA NASS (2021e) CORN - PROGRESS (planted, emerged, harvested) - 2000-2021. US Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service. https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov (direct query: https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/C4906A1B-9BAA-31C4-8033-B8D950FECC3E)

Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf
Prasuhn, V (2006) Erfassung der PO4-Austräge für die Ökobilanzierung. SALCA-Phosphor. Zü-rich, CH, Agrocope FAL Reckenholz. Agrocope.

Wohlgemuth, FHTW Berlin and A. Roches, R. Freiermuth Knuchel, Dr. G. Gaillard, Agroscope Reckenholz-Tänikon. 0.5112 ha/ha (4.16E-5 ha/kg maize grain) fertilising, by injection
Average application rates for mineral fertilisers (NPKS) on maize grain in Illinois are: 2.10 N applications on 98.3% of cropped area, 1.10 P applications on 85.8% of cropped area, 1.08 K applications on 80.0% of cropped area, and 1.15 S applications on 13.0% of cropped area (USDA NASS 2021f, NPKS data from 2014, 2016, 2018, 2021). Applications of N are split between anhydrous ammonia and other NPK(S) fertilsers because they are generally applied differently, with different equipment. Other than anhydrous ammonia, most NPK(S) fertilisers are applied together via broadcast application.
Anhydrous ammonia application (knifing/injection) is calculated as market share of N that is anhydrous ammonia * total N applications (=0.52). Other N application is then: total USDA N applications less applications of anhydrous ammonia (=1.58). The market share of N that is anhydrous ammonia is calculated from fertiliser market group shares crossed with meeting NPKS nutrient demand (here, 24.78%). Thus, the dataset includes 0.51 anhydrous ammonia applications via injection (0.52 * 98.3% of crop area with applied N) and 0.52 other N applications via broadcast.Since the number of passes for N application after removing the anhydrous ammonia share is greater than the maximum number of passes reported for the other nutrients, this dataset assumes that any other fertiliser applications are reflected under that pass and the total fertiliser broadcast fertiliser passes are thus 1.58.

Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance.  (Schnitkey G, Zulauf C, Swanson K, Paulson N 2021).  Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Where an operation applies only to a portion of the harvested area, the number of passes has been scaled by the % of harvested area to which it applies (e.g., manure spreading or insecticide) as indicated by USDA statistics (applications) or USDA reports (manure use) or as otherwise indicated in enterprise crop budgets.
Source(s): 
USDA NASS (2021f) CORN - APPLICATIONS, MEASURED IN LB / ACRE / YEAR, AVG and NUMBER / YEAR (fertilizer and pesticides, amount, number of applications) - 2000-2021. US Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service. https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov (direct query: https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/5BCE1263-5F91-31A9-B3DE-117AFBDDFF20); Schnitkey G, Zulauf C, Swanson K, Paulson N (2021) "2022 Updated Crop Budgets." farmdoc daily (11):162. Department of Agricultural and Consumer Economics. https://farmdocdaily.illinois.edu/2021/12/2022-updated-crop-budgets.html

NOx emissions from fertilizer and manure nitrification after N loss from NH3, as NO2. 7.08E+0 kg NO2/ha (5.76E-4kg NO2/kg maize grain), 6.96E+0 kg NO2/ha from fertilisers; 1.17E-1 kg NO2/ha from manure). Calculated according to EEA/EMEP guidance, EF_NO_Managed Soils = 0.04 kg NO2/kg N fertiliser and manure N applied (range 0.005 to 0.104, 95% CL), from Table 3.1, Tier 1 EFs for source category 3.D, EMEP/EEA Guidebook 2019. The differences between NO emissions from different application type, soil organic carbon levels, drainage or soil pH are not accounted for here.
Sources: 
EEA (2019a) EMEP/EEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook Part B: sectoral guidance chapters 3. Agriculture 3 D Crop production and agricultural soils. exchanges.description:
6.52E-3 kg NPK (15-15-15) fertiliser/kg maize grain 
Quantities of specific fertilisers are calculated based on US fertiliser market share and nutrient compositions from the International Fertilizer Association data to supply N to meet total nutrient demand N-P-K-S: 187.13--91.13--104.06--3.92 kg/ha (USDA NASS data for 2014, 2016, 2018, 2021; reflects average over all rotations and tillage regimes) over reported cropped area of specified crop (includes all rotation patterns), meeting N demand with the IFA mix and any remaining P, K, and S demands with other fertilisers balanced to avoid exceeding other demands by more than 1%. Quantity of specific fertiliser calculated from:  quantity of N applied to treated acres times percent of planted maize acres treated (USDA NASS) times share of N supplied by compound in U.S. consumption mix (ecoinvent and International Fertilizer Association 2019) times mass compound per mass N in compound.
Sources: 
USDA NASS (2021f) CORN - APPLICATIONS, MEASURED IN LB / ACRE / YEAR, AVG and NUMBER / YEAR (fertilizer and pesticides, amount, number of applications) - 2000-2021. US Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service. https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov (direct query: https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/5BCE1263-5F91-31A9-B3DE-117AFBDDFF20); USDA ERS Fertilizer and Price Data, updated 10/30/2019. https://www.ers.usda.gov/data-products/fertilizer-use-and-price/  USDA ERS. (2019). Table 9. Percent of corn acreage receiving nitrogen fertilizer, selected States. Fertilizer Use and Price Report. US Department of Agriculture (USDA) Economic Research Service (ERS). https://www.ers.usda.gov/data-products/fertilizer-use-and-price.aspx.
USDA ERS. (2019). Table 10. Nitrogen used on corn, rate per fertilized acre receiving nitrogen, selected States. Fertilizer Use and Price Report. US Department of Agriculture (USDA) Economic Research Service (ERS). https://www.ers.usda.gov/data-products/fertilizer-use-and-price.aspx; Ecoinvent U.S. consumption mix for N fertilisers, from IFA data; IFA (2021) Nutrient content in percentage - IFA Fertilizer Converter. Emissions of heavy metals to ground water arise from leaching. These emissions are estimated  based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production).  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils)Sources for heavy metals leaching to groundwater include: Leaching of heavy metals to groundwater (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where no drainage is installed ; the share of leaching to groundwater is calculated from Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (57.9%,) and ditch drainage (7.0%). USDA (2018) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf.
(N.B. The uncertainty associated with manure data increases the uncertainty of the heavy metal emissions.)
Sources:

1.81E-2 kg potassium chloride/kg maize grain 
Quantities of specific fertilisers are calculated based on US fertiliser market share and nutrient compositions from the International Fertilizer Association data to supply N to meet total nutrient demand N-P-K-S: 187.13--91.13--104.06--3.92 kg/ha (USDA NASS data for 2014, 2016, 2018, 2021; reflects average over all rotations and tillage regimes). The remaining K2O and S demands are met from a mix of ammonium sulfate, potassium nitrate, potassium chloride, and potassium sulfate, the quantities of which are determined by satisfying the demand without exceeding other nutrient demands by more than 1%, and any S demand remaining is met using elemental sulfur. 
 Quantity of specific fertiliser calculated from: average total N application times the share of each fertiliser in the U.S. consumption mix (ecoinvent and International Fertilizer Association 2019) times each fertiliser's K2O to N ratio (International Fertilizer Association) (the K2O supplied by meeting N demand), subtracted from the application rate for the necessary nutrient, and multiplied by the mass of the compound over the mass of K2O in the compound.
Sources: 
USDA NASS (2021f) CORN - APPLICATIONS, MEASURED IN LB / ACRE / YEAR, AVG and NUMBER / YEAR (fertilizer and pesticides, amount, number of applications) - 2000-2021. exchanges.description:
0.423 m3/ha (3.44E-5 m3/kg maize grain) liquid manure spreading, by vacuum tanker
The total effective manure application rate of 1,146 kg/ha (0.093 kg/kg maize grain) is calculated from USDA ERS data for amount of manure applied (18.7 T/ha; 1.52 kg/kg maize grain) on share of crop area treated (6.1%)  (years available: 2005, 2010) (USDA ARMS 2015a). The manure data has significant uncertainty due to both the age of the available data and the statistical limitations imposed by confidentiality for USDA survey respondents.
About 37% of applied manure is in liquid form, calculated from the share of dry, semi-dry and slurry and lagoon manure applied  from ARMS data.  100% of manure from cattle. The state's USDA manure table shows zero share from either swine or poultry manures.  
 Cattle manure is apportioned between solid and liquid consistent with USDA esimtated shares.
The calculated solid and liquid manure shares in this dataset are thus 37.2% solid and 62.8% liquid manure. The effective application rates are 719.8 kg solid manure per ha (3.44E-5 kg/kg maize grain) and .4 m3 liquid manure per ha (3.44E-5 m3/kg maize grain).

Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance.  (Schnitkey G, Zulauf C, Swanson K, Paulson N 2021).  Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Where an operation applies only to a portion of the harvested area, the number of passes has been scaled by the % of harvested area to which it applies (e.g., manure spreading or insecticide) as indicated by USDA statistics (applications) or USDA reports (manure use) or as otherwise indicated in enterprise crop budgets. 
Source(s): 
USDA ARMS (2015a) Agricultural Resource Management Survey (ARMS) Farm Financial and Crop Production Practices: Manure Table, Corn. USDA. https://data.ers.usda.gov/reports.aspx?ID=17883
Beegle D and Peters J. (2019) Common Manure Test Results Conversions. National Cooperative Extension Resource, Livestock And Poultry Environmental Learning Community (Lpelc). https://lpelc.org/common-manure-test-results-conversions/accessed October 5, 2021
Wilson M (2021) Manure Characteristics. University of Minnesota Extension. https://extension.umn.edu/manure-management/manure-characteristics; https://drive.google.com/file/d/1-c8bx_75YSsQZTNFB_YFVD-uw_SbX1dB/view?usp=sharing
Schnitkey G, Zulauf C, Swanson K, Paulson N (2021) "2022 Updated Crop Budgets." farmdoc daily (11):162. Department of Agricultural and Consumer Economics. https://farmdocdaily.illinois.edu/2021/12/2022-updated-crop-budgets.html

exchanges.description:
0.3624 ha/ha (2.95E-5 ha/kg maize grain) application of plant protection product, by airplane
The dataset has an effective number of passes for application of pesticides of 1.54 ha: 1.09 applications of herbicides on 98.0% of cropped area, 1.03 applications of insecticides on 20.3% of cropped area, 1.12 applications of fungicides on 23.7% of cropped area (USDA NASS 2021f). Application by sprayer accounts for 76% (1.18 passes) and aircraft for 24% (0.36 passes). The budgets for maize grain in Illinois do not provide information for aerial pesticide application as an individual operation.  However, aerial application is in common use in Illinois. An aerial pesticide application rate of  24% has been estimated from custom rate surveys for contracted farm operations.
Because aerial application is almost universally contracted service, it is most often not included in crop-specific enterprise budgets as a separate line item, instead being included under "custom" or "miscellaneous". Consequently, this dataset uses  the ratio of custom farm rate survey responses for aerial application to the total respondents to provide a state crop level average estimate of aerial applications.  This value covers all farmers responding and does not distinguish among crops. Illinois does not collect custom rate surveys. The Iowa Custom Rate Surveys, cited most widely in farm economics projections lacking the state's own Survey, average 24% 2018-2021 (Plastina A and Johanns A 2021, 2020, 2019, 2018).  The National Agricultural Aviation Association estimates that approximately 28% of all US cropland (excluding range, pasture, and forest lands) is treated by aircraft annually (NAAA 2019, NAAA 2020).
Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance.  (Schnitkey G, Zulauf C, Swanson K, Paulson N 2021).  Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Where an operation applies only to a portion of the harvested area, the number of passes has been scaled by the % of harvested area to which it applies (e.g., manure spreading or insecticide) as indicated by USDA statistics (applications) or USDA reports (manure use) or as otherwise indicated in enterprise crop budgets.
Source(s): 
Plastina A and Johanns A (2021) Iowa Farm Custom Rate Survey, 2021 (2018, 2019, 2020). Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology. https://www.extension.iastate.edu/agdm/crops/pdf/a3-10.pdf; Plastina, Johanns, Massman (2020) 2020 Iowa Farm Custom Rate Survey File A3-10. Emissions of heavy metals to surface water arise from leaching (when drainage is present) and erosion. Emissions are estimated  based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils)

Transformation of land for planting.  Land is under rotation with other annual crop production (~80% corn-soy, ~20% corn-corn, Socolar et al 2021).  US NRCS data indicates that land is leaving agricultural production rather than being transitioned into it (NRCS 2020b), resulting in a flux to/from annual crop that is essentially steady state. 
Annual production is 54.8 million tonnes from 2017-2021 on 4.6 million ha planted and 4.5 million ha harvested (USDA NASS 2021d). Thus occupation is 0.81 ha/t or 8,140.93 m2/t (0.8141 m2/kg). This overall land use is split into irrigated (1.36%) and non-irrigated (98.64%) based on agricultural census data (USDA NASS 2021d) (1.1E-2 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of irrigated land, and 8.03E-1 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of non-irrigated land).

Emissions of heavy metals to surface water arise from leaching (when drainage is present) and erosion. exchanges.description:
Application of limestone to raise soil pH, 140.16 kg/ha (1.14E-2 kg/kg maize grain), calculated as the (mass of lime applied to treated acres (2 t/treated ha)) * fraction of crop area treated with lime (19.85%, from soil pH data from Bruulsema T and Jones J D 2021) / (7  years between applications, based on Fernández F G and Hoeft R G  2012a). 
Lime is applied to all soils with pH below 6 based on expert guidance (Sawyer JE 2020). Cropped area needing liming is determined from  distribution of soil pH sampling results reported in the 2020 Soil Test Summary (Bruulsema and Jones 2021). The share of acidic soils is likely overestimated as more more frequent testing is to be expected on soils having needed lime and thus low pH soils are likely to be more represented amongst the collected samples. (Mallarino A P, Pagani A, Sawyer J E 2011; Fernández F G and Hoeft R G  2012; Bly A and Gelderman R 2019; Shaver T M 2014) The increase in pH with lime application remains dominant through at least 4 years from application and guidance suggests 4 to 10 years beween applications (Fernández F G and Hoeft R G  2012).
Sources: 
Bruulsema T and Jones J D (2021) Soil Test Summary 2020. Foundation for Agronomic Research and Plant Nutrition Canada present this 2020 summary of soil test levels in North America. Foundation for Agronomic Research, Plant Nutrition Canada. https://soiltest.tfi.org/about/about_soil_test_summaryaccessed August 30, 2021; Fernández F G and Hoeft R G  (2012a) Managing Soil pH and Crop Nutrients. Chapter 8 in the Illinois Agronomy Handbook.Crop Science Extension & Outreach, University of Illinois . http://extension.cropsciences.illinois.edu/handbook/pdfs/chapter08.pdf; Shaver T M (2014) Nutrient Management for Agronomic Crops in Nebraska (rev Dec 2014). The University of Nebraska Institute of Agriculture and Natural Resources. https://extensionpublications.unl.edu/assets/pdf/ec155.pdfaccessed August 30, 2021; Bly A and Gelderman R (2019) Chapter: 25 Liming South Dakota Soils . SDSU Extension . https://extension.sdstate.edu/sites/default/files/2019-09/S-0003-25-Corn.pdf; Mallarino A P, Pagani A, Sawyer J E (2011) Corn and soybean response to soil pH level and liming. Paper presented at the 2011 Integrated Crop Management Conference. Iowa State University.Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology. https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/128983337.pdfaccessed November 17, 2021

exchanges.description:
1.552 ha/ha (1.26E-4 ha/kg maize grain) fertilising, by broadcaster
Average application rates for mineral fertilisers (NPKS) on maize grain in Illinois are: 2.10 N applications on 98.3% of cropped area, 1.10 P applications on 85.8% of cropped area, 1.08 K applications on 80.0% of cropped area, and 1.15 S applications on 13.0% of cropped area (USDA NASS 2021f, NPKS data from 2014, 2016, 2018, 2021). Applications of N are split between anhydrous ammonia and other NPK(S) fertilsers because they are generally applied differently, with different equipment. Other than anhydrous ammonia, most NPK(S) fertilisers are applied together via broadcast application.
Anhydrous ammonia application (knifing/injection) is calculated as market share of N that is anhydrous ammonia * total N applications (=0.52). Other N application is then: total USDA N applications less applications of anhydrous ammonia (=1.58). The market share of N that is anhydrous ammonia is calculated from fertiliser market group shares crossed with meeting NPKS nutrient demand (here, 24.78%). Thus, the dataset includes 0.51 anhydrous ammonia applications via injection (0.52 * 98.3% of crop area with applied N) and 1.55 other N applications via broadcast (1.58 * 98.3%). Since the number of passes for N application after removing the anhydrous ammonia share is greater than the maximum number of passes reported for the other nutrients, this dataset assumes that any other fertiliser applications are reflected under that pass and the total fertiliser broadcast fertiliser passes are thus 1.55.

Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance.  (Schnitkey G, Zulauf C, Swanson K, Paulson N 2021).  Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Where an operation applies only to a portion of the harvested area, the number of passes has been scaled by the % of harvested area to which it applies (e.g., manure spreading or insecticide) as indicated by USDA statistics (applications) or USDA reports (manure use) or as otherwise indicated in enterprise crop budgets.
Source(s): 
USDA NASS (2021f) CORN - APPLICATIONS, MEASURED IN LB / ACRE / YEAR, AVG and NUMBER / YEAR (fertilizer and pesticides, amount, number of applications) - 2000-2021. US Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service. https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov (direct query: https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/5BCE1263-5F91-31A9-B3DE-117AFBDDFF20); Schnitkey G, Zulauf C, Swanson K, Paulson N (2021) "2022 Updated Crop Budgets." farmdoc daily (11):162. Department of Agricultural and Consumer Economics. https://farmdocdaily.illinois.edu/2021/12/2022-updated-crop-budgets.html

exchanges.description:
Ammonia volatilised from applied mineral and organic fertilisers, 18.4 kg NH3/ha (1.5E-3kg NH3/kg maize grain) total, 16.0 kg NH3/ha (1.5E-3 kg NH3/kg maize grain) from synthetic fertilisers, 2.5 kg NH3/ha (2.02E-4 kg NH3/kg maize grain) from manure. NH3 from volatilisation of mineral fertilisers is calculated using Tier 2 emission factors (temperate climate, specific fertiliser) from the European Environment Agency, EMEP/EEA 3Da1, Table3.2 (EEA 2019). NH3 from manure application is calculated with emission factors provided in EMEP/EEA 3.D.a.2.a (Animal manure applied to soils) (EEA 2019) for manure types used as (fraction TAN in total N)*(EF manure spreading per TAN) for each animal group and type. (kg NH3-N/kg N applied: cattle, solid: 0.474; cattle, liquid: 0.33). The emissions from manure calculated here do not account for the change in N mineralization and phosphate runoff with incorporation type or time. Where impacts from manure application are expected to be significant, this should be considered as N volatilisation during and after application of manure ranges from as low as 1% N with direct injection to ~5% with immediate incorporation to 20-40% without incorporation (Sawyer J, Mallarino A P (2016) Using Manure Nutrients for Crop Production. Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology. https://store.extension.iastate.edu/product/12874and Midwast Plan Services MWPS-18, 3ed)..  NH3 from volatilisation of mineral fertilisers is calculated using Tier 2 emission factors (temperate climate, specific fertiliser) from the European Environment Agency, EMEP/EEA 3Da1, Table3.2 (EEA 2019). NH3 from manure application is calculated with emission factors provided in EMEP/EEA 3.D.a.2.a (Animal manure applied to soils) (EEA 2019) for manure types used as (fraction TAN in total N)*(EF manure spreading per TAN) for each animal group and type. (kg NH3-N/kg N applied: cattle, solid: 0.474; cattle, liquid: 0.33). The emissions from manure calculated here do not account for the change in N mineralization and phosphate runoff with incorporation type or time. Where impacts from manure application are expected to be significant, this should be considered as N volatilisation during and after application of manure ranges from as low as 1% N with direct injection to ~5% with immediate incorporation to 20-40% without incorporation (Sawyer J, Mallarino A P (2016) Using Manure Nutrients for Crop Production. Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology. https://store.extension.iastate.edu/product/12874and Midwast Plan Services MWPS-18, 3ed).
Sources: 
EEA (2019a) EMEP/EEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook Part B: sectoral guidance chapters 3. Agriculture 3 D Crop production and agricultural soils. European Environment Agency. https://www.eea.europa.eu/publications/emep-eea-guidebook-2019/part-b-sectoral-guidance-chapters/4-agriculture/3-d-crop-production-and/view 
EEA (2019b) EMEP/EEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook Part B: sectoral guidance chapters 3. Agriculture 3 B Manure management. exchanges.description:
Each planted hectare uses 22.37 kg seed (1.82E-3 kg/kg maize grain). This value is calculated from a seeding rate of 83,475 seeds/ha (Licht M, Parvej M R, Baum M 2019, Licht M 2020) and an average seed count of 3,732 seeds/kg (averaged from Licht M and Clemens Z 2020, Leinfelder-Miles M 2018). More than 90% of planted maize corn is genetically engineered (state by state variation 0.3-1.8%), mostly with stacked herbicide-tolerant and insect-tolerant traits (USDA NASS 2022). The dataset uses the less variable agronomically optimal seeding rate rather than the more variable, though potentially lower, economically optimal rate. Germination and stand losses are accounted for in the seeding rate. The uncertainty parameters are calculated from the uncertainty on the yield and the  year on year variation on the order of 6-17% found in analysis of USDA NASS data for 2014-2016 (Mekonnen et al 2018).  
Sources:
Lindsey AJ, Thomison PR, Nafziger ED  (2018) Estimated Return-to-Seed of Variable vs. Uniform Corn Seeding Rates. Crop Ecophysiology and Agronomy, Ohio State University; Corn Cropping Systems Extension, Ohio State University; Crop Sciences, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. https://ohioline.osu.edu/factsheet/agf-520, USDA NASS. (2020). Crops/Stocks Survey (or Agricultural Survey) for the years 2000-20 - Recent Trends in GE Adoption. US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.ers.usda.gov/data-products/adoption-of-genetically-engineered-crops-in-the-us/documentation/ , Mekonnen et al (2018) Water, Energy, and Carbon Footprints of Bioethanol from the U.S. and Brazil. Environ. Sci. Technol. 52:14508–14518. Mesfin M. Mekonnen, Thiago L. Romanelli, Chittaranjan Ray, Arjen Y. Hoekstra, Adam J. Liska, and Christopher M.U. Neale. https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.est.8b03359

exchanges.description:
Transformation of land for planting.  Land is under rotation with other annual crop production (~80% corn-soy, ~20% corn-corn, Socolar et al 2021).  US NRCS data indicates that land is leaving agricultural production rather than being transitioned into it (NRCS 2020b), resulting in a flux to/from annual crop that is essentially steady state. 
Annual production is 54.8 million tonnes from 2017-2021 on 4.6 million ha planted and 4.5 million ha harvested (USDA NASS 2021d). Thus occupation is 0.81 ha/t or 8,140.93 m2/t (0.8141 m2/kg). This overall land use is split into irrigated (1.36%) and non-irrigated (98.64%) based on agricultural census data (USDA NASS 2021d) (1.1E-2 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of irrigated land, and 8.03E-1 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of non-irrigated land).

USDA NASS (2021d) Area, Production, Yield by State - Corn - 2010-2021. US Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service. https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov (direct query: https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/331F88CC-004E-34D2-B825-F8F65DAC7879)

Emissions of heavy metals to ground water arise from leaching. These emissions are estimated  based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production).  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils)Sources for heavy metals leaching to groundwater include: Leaching of heavy metals to groundwater (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where no drainage is installed ; the share of leaching to groundwater is calculated from Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (57.9%,) and ditch drainage (7.0%). USDA (2018) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). 3.47E-2 kg cattle manure/kg maize grain
The total effective manure application rate of 1,146 kg/ha (0.093 kg/kg maize grain) is calculated from USDA ERS data for amount of manure applied (18.7 T/ha; 1.52 kg/kg maize grain) on share of crop area treated (6.1%)  (years available: 2005, 2010) (USDA ARMS 2015a). The manure data has significant uncertainty due to both the age of the available data and the statistical limitations imposed by confidentiality for USDA survey respondents.
About 37% of applied manure is in liquid form, calculated from the share of dry, semi-dry and slurry and lagoon manure applied  from ARMS data.  100% of manure from cattle. The state's USDA manure table shows zero share from either swine or poultry manures.  
 Cattle manure is apportioned between solid and liquid consistent with USDA esimtated shares.
The calculated solid and liquid manure shares in this dataset are thus 37.2% solid and 62.8% liquid manure.  Volume of liquid manure is calculated using density ~8.4lb/gal (8-9 lb/gal, Wilson M 2021). Total mass liquid manure is 3.47E-2 kg/kg maize grain, total volume of liquid manure is 3.44E-5 m3/kg maize.
Sources:
Wilson M (2021) Manure Characteristics. University of Minnesota Extension. https://extension.umn.edu/manure-management/manure-characteristics; https://drive.google.com/file/d/1-c8bx_75YSsQZTNFB_YFVD-uw_SbX1dB/view?usp=sharing
Beegle D and Peters J. (2019) Common Manure Test Results Conversions. National Cooperative Extension Resource, Livestock And Poultry Environmental Learning Community (Lpelc). https://lpelc.org/common-manure-test-results-conversions/accessed October 5, 2021
USDA ARMS (2015a) Agricultural Resource Management Survey (ARMS) Farm Financial and Crop Production Practices: Manure Table, Corn. USDA. https://data.ers.usda.gov/reports.aspx?ID=17883

exchanges.description:
1.63E-4 ha/kg tillage, field cultivator (2. effective pass(es) per year). 
Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance. Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Field cultivation and tillage operations are specific to the tillage regime used.  The rotation pattern also dictates some tillage patterns, captured in the GIS data for tillage shares. Maize cultivation is 73% reduced till, 18% conventional tillage, and 9% no till in Illinois (CTIC 2020a). This operation applies to fields under all tillage regimes. 
Sources:
Schnitkey G, Zulauf C, Swanson K, Paulson N (2021) "2022 Updated Crop Budgets." farmdoc daily (11):162. 0.028 ha/ha (2.31E-6 ha/kg maize grain), calculated as the fraction of crop area treated with lime (19.85%, from state level estimated agricultural acres with pH <6.1, Bruulsema T and Jones J D 2021)  / (7  years between applications, based on Bruulsema T and Jones J D 2021).
Lime is applied to all soils with pH below 6 based on expert guidance (Sawyer JE 2020). Cropped area needing liming is determined from  distribution of soil pH sampling results reported in the 2020 Soil Test Summary (Bruulsema and Jones 2021). The share of acidic soils is likely overestimated as more more frequent testing is to be expected on soils having needed lime and thus low pH soils are likely to be more represented amongst the collected samples. Emissions of heavy metals to ground water arise from leaching. These emissions are estimated  based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production).  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils)Sources for heavy metals leaching to groundwater include: Leaching of heavy metals to groundwater (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where no drainage is installed ; the share of leaching to groundwater is calculated from Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (57.9%,) and ditch drainage (7.0%). USDA (2018) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf.
(N.B. The uncertainty associated with manure data increases the uncertainty of the heavy metal emissions.)

1.45E-5 ha/kg planting (0.178 effective pass(es) per year). 
Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance. Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Field cultivation and tillage operations are specific to the tillage regime used.  The rotation pattern also dictates some tillage patterns, captured in the GIS data for tillage shares. Maize cultivation is 73% reduced till, 18% conventional tillage, and 9% no till in Illinois (CTIC 2020a). Sowing with till and no-till planters based on share of field type. Planting on no till fields only.

exchanges.description:
Emissions of heavy metals to soil are estimated based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The balance of heavy metal emissions to soils includes the net change from erosion, leaching, crop removal and fertilizer, manure, lime, planting and deposition.  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Heavy-metal contents of plant material, maize (mg/kg dry matter, from Freiermuth 2006). ; Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). state and regional erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (57.9%,) and ditch drainage (7.0%). USDA (2018) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf. Fertilizer, manure and pesticide application rates are based on USDA NASS data.
(N.B. The uncertainty associated with manure data increases the uncertainty of the heavy metal emissions.)

Transformation of land for planting.  Land is under rotation with other annual crop production (~80% corn-soy, ~20% corn-corn, Socolar et al 2021).  US NRCS data indicates that land is leaving agricultural production rather than being transitioned into it (NRCS 2020b), resulting in a flux to/from annual crop that is essentially steady state. 
Annual production is 54.8 million tonnes from 2017-2021 on 4.6 million ha planted and 4.5 million ha harvested (USDA NASS 2021d). Thus occupation is 0.81 ha/t or 8,140.93 m2/t (0.8141 m2/kg). This overall land use is split into irrigated (1.36%) and non-irrigated (98.64%) based on agricultural census data (USDA NASS 2021d) (1.1E-2 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of irrigated land, and 8.03E-1 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of non-irrigated land).

The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Heavy-metal contents of plant material, maize (mg/kg dry matter, from Freiermuth 2006). ; Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). state and regional erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (57.9%,) and ditch drainage (7.0%). USDA (2018) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf. Fertilizer, manure and pesticide application rates are based on USDA NASS data.
(N.B. The uncertainty associated with manure data increases the uncertainty of the heavy metal emissions.)
Sources:
Freiermuth (2006) SALCA-Schwermetall - Modell zur Berechnung der Schwermetall- flüsse in der Landwirtschaftlichen Ökobilanz. Agroscope FAL Zürich-Reckenholz . https://www.agroscope.admin.ch/dam/agroscope/de/dokumente/themen/umwelt-ressourcen/produktionssysteme/salca-schwermetall.pdf.download.pdf/SALCA-Schwermetall.pdf 
Faist Emmenegger M, Reinhard J, Zah R (2009) Sustainability Quick Check for Biofuels - in- termediate background report. With contributions from T. Ziep, R. Weichbrodt, Prof. Dr. V. Wohlgemuth, FHTW Berlin and A. Roches, R. Freiermuth Knuchel, Dr. G. Gaillard, Agroscope Reckenholz-Tänikon. Dübendorf. . https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Rainer-Zah/publication/230725635_SQCB_-_Sustainability_Quick_Check_for_Biofuels_Second_draft_18th_February_2009_-_Intermediate_Background_Report_With_contributions_from_T_Ziep_R_Weichbrodt_Prof_Dr_V_Wohlgemuth_FHTW_Berlin_and_A_Roche/links/56b458fb08ae1f8aa45392e6/SQCB-Sustainability-Quick-Check-for-Biofuels-Second-draft-18th-February-2009-Intermediate-Background-Report-With-contributions-from-T-Ziep-R-Weichbrodt-Prof-Dr-V-Wohlgemuth-FHTW-Berlin-and-A-R.pdf

Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté  (2018) 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production.

The gross energy content of maize grain is 18.7MJ/kg on a dry matter basis, 87.2% dry matter as fed for North American maize grain (Feedipedia - Maize 2017). At the harvest moisture content of 19.4% (2014-2021, USDA NASS 2021a), the energy content of maize grain is 15.1MJ/kg product weight.

Quantities of specific fertilisers are calculated based on US fertiliser market share and nutrient compositions from the International Fertilizer Association data to supply N to meet total nutrient demand N-P-K-S: 187.13--91.13--104.06--3.92 kg/ha (USDA NASS data for 2014, 2016, 2018, 2021; reflects average over all rotations and tillage regimes) over reported cropped area of specified crop (includes all rotation patterns), meeting N demand with the IFA mix and any remaining P, K, and S demands with other fertilisers balanced to avoid exceeding other demands by more than 1%. Quantity of specific fertiliser calculated from:  quantity of N applied to treated acres times percent of planted maize acres treated (USDA NASS) times share of N supplied by compound in U.S. consumption mix (ecoinvent and International Fertilizer Association 2019) times mass compound per mass N in compound.

Emissions of heavy metals to surface water arise from leaching (when drainage is present) and erosion. Emissions are estimated  based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils)

1.5379 ha/ha (1.25E-4 ha/kg maize grain) market for application of plant protection product, by sprayer
The dataset has an effective number of passes for application of pesticides of 1.54 ha: 1.09 applications of herbicides on 98.0% of cropped area, 1.03 applications of insecticides on 20.3% of cropped area, 1.12 applications of fungicides on 23.7% of cropped area (USDA NASS 2021f). Application by sprayer accounts for 76% (1.18 passes) and aircraft for 24% (0.36 passes). The budgets for maize grain in Illinois do not provide information for aerial pesticide application as an individual operation.  However, aerial application is in common use in Illinois. An aerial pesticide application rate of  24% has been estimated from custom rate surveys for contracted farm operations.
Because aerial application is almost universally contracted service, it is most often not included in crop-specific enterprise budgets as a separate line item, instead being included under "custom" or "miscellaneous". Consequently, this dataset uses  the ratio of custom farm rate survey responses for aerial application to the total respondents to provide a state crop level average estimate of aerial applications.  This value covers all farmers responding and does not distinguish among crops. Illinois does not collect custom rate surveys. The Iowa Custom Rate Surveys, cited most widely in farm economics projections lacking the state's own Survey, average 24% 2018-2021 (Plastina A and Johanns A 2021, 2020, 2019, 2018).  The National Agricultural Aviation Association estimates that approximately 28% of all US cropland (excluding range, pasture, and forest lands) is treated by aircraft annually (NAAA 2019, NAAA 2020).
Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance.  (Schnitkey G, Zulauf C, Swanson K, Paulson N 2021).  Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Where an operation applies only to a portion of the harvested area, the number of passes has been scaled by the % of harvested area to which it applies (e.g., manure spreading or insecticide) as indicated by USDA statistics (applications) or USDA reports (manure use) or as otherwise indicated in enterprise crop budgets.
Source(s): 
Plastina A and Johanns A (2021) Iowa Farm Custom Rate Survey, 2021 (2018, 2019, 2020). Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology. https://www.extension.iastate.edu/agdm/crops/pdf/a3-10.pdf; Plastina, Johanns, Massman (2020) 2020 Iowa Farm Custom Rate Survey File A3-10. Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology. https://iastate.app.box.com/embed/s/hbsel0lckc7vle74v4jkg7mf0ph3z39s/file/630724245464; Plastina, Johanns, Wynne (2019) 2019 Iowa Farm Custom Rate Survey File A3-10. Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology. https://www.extension.iastate.edu/hancock/sites/www.extension.iastate.edu/files/hancock/2018_CustomRateSurvey.pdf; NAAA (2020) Letter to the South Dakota Public Utilities Commission, July 30, 2020.
